bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: "A Word about Tennyson"
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

The prose drafted on the back of these and several other related manuscript leaves includes ideas and phrases that resemble those used in "Unnamed Lands," a poem published first in the 1860 edition of Leaves of Grass.

body.note: follow copy—punctuation&c—If possible send me a proof Saturday night—which I will return Sunday night WW—Camden New Jersey
body.head: A Word about Tennyson
body.p:
¶ Beautiful as the song was, the original "Locksley Hall" of half a century ago seems was essentially morbid, heart⹀broken, finding fault with every thing, especially the fact of money's being made (as it ever must be, and perhaps should be) the para-
mountparamount matter in worldly affairs.

lg.l: ("Every door is barr'd with gold, and opens but to golden keys.")

body.p: ]First, a father, having fallen in battle, his child, (the singer)

lg.l: was left a trampled orphan, and a selfish uncle's ward."

body.p: ]Of course love ensues. The woman woman in the chant or monologue proves a false one; and as far as appears the ideal of Woman, ‸ in the poet's reflections, is a false one, at any rate for America. Woman is not "the lesser man." (The heart is not the brain.) The best of the piece of fifty years since is its concluding line:
type "For the mighty wind arises roaring seaward, and I go."

] Then for ‸ this current 1886-'7, comes a a just⹀out se- quelsequel, which, ( as an apparently authentic summary says), "rReviews the life of mankind during the past sixty years, and comes to the conclusion that its boasted progress is of doubtful credit to the world in general and to England in particular. A cynical vein of denunciation of democratic opinions and aspirations runs throughout the poem, in marked contrast with the spirit of the "Locksley Hall" of the poet's youth."‸ "/ Among the most striking lines ‸ of this sequel are the following: smaller typeEnvy wears the mask of love
